subject: Fix NTPServers are hard-coded for eth0
commitMessage:
Fix NTPServers are hard-coded for eth0

Since bmcweb is getting and patching NTPServers only from
'/xyz/openbmc_project/network/eth0' object, and this is hard-coded, if
we use eth1, it will broken the NTP configuration and fail to route to
the correct NTPServer.

All NTPServers of xyz.openbmc_project.Network.EthernetInterface
interface should be updated.

Tested:
1. When NTPServer is set through the webUI, all NTPs of the
Ethernet will be updated synchronously.
2. If eth1 is ethernet.
doPatch:
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -X PATCH -d '{ "NTP":{"NTPServers": ["192.168.1.2", "192.168.1.1"], "ProtocolEnabled": true}}' https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/NetworkProtocol

doGet:
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/NetworkProtocol
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/NetworkProtocol",
  "@odata.type": "#ManagerNetworkProtocol.v1_5_0.ManagerNetworkProtocol",
  "Description": "Manager Network Service",
  "NTP": {
    "NTPServers": [
      "192.168.1.2",
      "192.168.1.1"
    ],
    "ProtocolEnabled": true
  },
  ...
}

3. cat 00-bmc-eth0.network
[Match]
Name=eth0
[Link]
MACAddress=52:54:00:12:34:56
[Network]
LinkLocalAddressing=yes
IPv6AcceptRA=true
NTP=192.168.1.1
NTP=192.168.1.2
DHCP=true
[DHCP]
ClientIdentifier=mac
UseDNS=true
UseNTP=true
UseHostname=true
SendHostname=true

4. cat 00-bmc-eth1.network
[Match]
Name=eth1
[Link]
MACAddress=52:54:00:12:34:57
[Network]
LinkLocalAddressing=yes
IPv6AcceptRA=true
NTP=192.168.1.1
NTP=192.168.1.2
DHCP=true
[DHCP]
ClientIdentifier=mac
UseDNS=true
UseNTP=true
UseHostname=true
SendHostname=true

Signed-off-by: George Liu <liuxiwei@inspur.com>
Change-Id: I624afa4154464524792d072966bf1ee9db594661

Left comments, but overall, there's two things to finish on this patchset:

1. Write the code such that the NTP server ordering is obeyed.  A user PATCHing the property should not get a different order back than the one they sent in.
2. Define behavior when the interfaces don't match.  I suspect this should involve just reading from the first interface and relaying that list, but I could be convinced it should be the full interface list with duplicates removed, so long as #1 is still obeyed, and we have consistent, user driven ordering.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 0a052baa566b3697419789dbf78934d43efc4ac4 by Ed Tanous
50/72 please.
Done
Why is the NTPServer interface per-nic at all?  This seems like a phosphor-dbus-interfaces issue that needs fixed to make the NtpServers attribute settable systemwide, not per nic.

I re-read through this patch, and while I still don't think the dbus interfaces are great here, I'm ok with us taking the approach of "Set NTP servers on the first interface we find" as a temporary solution.  Lets get the code cleaned up, and this should be fine.

> Why is the NTPServer interface per-nic at all?  This seems like a phosphor-dbus-interfaces issue that needs fixed to make the NtpServers attribute settable systemwide, not per nic.

Yes, I think the best result should be that there is one in the xyz.openbmc_project.Network.EthernetInterface interface to identify whether the current Ethernet is active.

> I re-read through this patch, and while I still don't think the dbus interfaces are great here, I'm ok with us taking the approach of "Set NTP servers on the first interface we find" as a temporary solution.  Lets get the code cleaned up, and this should be fine.

For systems that do not use eth0 by default, this is a bug. It cannot update NTPServer correctly, which will cause NTP synchronization to fail.

Or we can use a global configuration to get the information of the currently active network card, like this:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47342/1

@edtanous, NTP server should be per interface basis, Systemd networkd also supports that.
However Redfish DMTF doesn't model things that way because that brings more complexity.

The primary bug with this is that the response no longer follows restful CRUD semantics, because the response is sorted and aggregated between all the various things.

For example, if I called
PATCH NTPServers: ["2.2.2.2", "1.1.1.1"]
Then got a 200 back, re-reading would result in:
GET NTPServers:["1.1.1.1", "2.2.2.2"]
Which is a bug.  Ordering should not be changed server-side.

There's also a lot of questions around if we're looking at multiple interfaces, what happens when they don't contain the same data?  This patchset defines the behavior as "the superset of all interfaces", but that doesn't really follow CRUD either, because any modification to that, will now set it on all interfaces.


"to identify whether the current Ethernet is active."
That doesn't seem like it would matter in this case?

> @edtanous, NTP server should be per interface basis, Systemd networkd also supports that.

Feel free to propose that to DMTF then?  In this context we're discussing how to get the existing interfaces to work and follow Restful semantics given that they don't match.  The initial patchset for this defaulted everything to eth0, because it was assumed that all BMCs had a dedicated NIC at the time.  That assumption clearly doesn't work for those platforms, so we need to figure out defined behavior for those cases.  Clearly my "set it on the first interface found" idea wouldn't meet the needs, but we need to come up with something that has defined, CRUD behavior, even when the interfaces don't match.  That might involve a change to the phosphor-networkd interfaces for this, but we'll see.
Also, please answer these questions of CRUD behavior when the interfaces are different in your commit message.

> The primary bug with this is that the response no longer follows restful CRUD semantics, because the response is sorted and aggregated between all the various things.

This is handled in bmcweb, but I don't understand why the restful CRUD is not followed after sorting? Does this have any effect?
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/network_protocol.hpp#L419-L423

> That doesn't seem like it would matter in this case?

Why? If we know which Ethernet is active, it is very convenient for us to update NTPServers.

> Also, please answer these questions of CRUD behavior when the interfaces are different in your commit message.

Ack

> > The primary bug with this is that the response no longer follows restful CRUD semantics, because the response is sorted and aggregated between all the various things.
> 
> This is handled in bmcweb, but I don't understand why the restful CRUD is not followed after sorting?

See the section where I say "for example, if I called".  we should be writing the value as written, unless given special directives, like null, which redfish has specific non-crud rules for.

> Does this have any effect?
> https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/network_protocol.hpp#L419-L423
> 
> > That doesn't seem like it would matter in this case?
> 
> Why? If we know which Ethernet is active, it is very convenient for us to update NTPServers.

I see no "active" check in this code.  If we were selecting ONE interface, that might be fine, or if we had a way to consistently do the "merge" of the interfaces, that might work fine too, but as written, this doesn't fit the rest semantics.

> 
> > Also, please answer these questions of CRUD behavior when the interfaces are different in your commit message.
> 
> Ack

> See the section where I say "for example, if I called".  we should be writing the value as written, unless given special directives, like null, which redfish has specific non-crud rules for.

Okay, got it.

> I see no "active" check in this code.  If we were selecting ONE interface, that might be fine, or if we had a way to consistently do the "merge" of the interfaces, that might work fine too, but as written, this doesn't fit the rest semantics.

Do you agree this way?
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47342/1

Or, Do you have any good opinions on this bug?

> There's also a lot of questions around if we're looking at multiple interfaces, what happens when they don't contain the same data?  This patchset defines the behavior as "the superset of all interfaces", but that doesn't really follow CRUD either, because any modification to that, will now set it on all interfaces.

Before we get DMTF update on Redfish schema, I prefer to set the same NTP servers for multiple interfaces, which does resolve the problem.
From the Reffish perspective, we are sure that all the interfaces contain the same NTP data as long as we set the same data to all the interfaces.

> > There's also a lot of questions around if we're looking at multiple interfaces, what happens when they don't contain the same data?  This patchset defines the behavior as "the superset of all interfaces", but that doesn't really follow CRUD either, because any modification to that, will now set it on all interfaces.
> 
> Before we get DMTF update on Redfish schema, I prefer to set the same NTP servers for multiple interfaces, which does resolve the problem.

It doesn't resolve the fact that we now have two sources of truth for the list of NTP servers.  When they differ between the interfaces, we have undefined behavior.

> From the Reffish perspective, we are sure that all the interfaces contain the same NTP data as long as we set the same data to all the interfaces.

I'd accept a patch that did that, so long as it fixes the CRUD ordering problem, and has well defined behavior on set, it seems reasonable to set it on all interfaces, but this patchset doesn't currently do that.  It sorts, and deduplicates, rather than just deduplicating, which leads to a reordering of servers when the user sets them.

In this case the order actually does matter, as it sets a priority list, so we can't just arbitrarily sort it alphabetically on hostname.

> Do you agree this way?

I don't understand, you've linked the same patchset we're currently discussing.

> I'd accept a patch that did that, so long as it fixes the CRUD ordering problem, and has well defined behavior on set, it seems reasonable to set it on all interfaces, but this patchset doesn't currently do that.  It sorts, and deduplicates, rather than just deduplicating, which leads to a reordering of servers when the user sets them.

Ed, I have updated this patch.

Also, I have fixed the CRUD ordering problem in this patch:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47344

> I don't understand, you've linked the same patchset we're currently discussing.

The original idea was to use global configuration to solve this problem, which is in patch set-1.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47342/1
However, it seems that this approach is likely to be unacceptable.
Once we match the interface, should we stop looping with a break right here?  That would remove the need to do the "remove duplicates" thing below.

I do not think so.
We have two ethernets, eth0 and eth1, and we are using eth1 by default, and the first match will match eth0, which is wrong for our system.
FWIW, this shouldn't be EthernetInterface, this should be ManagerNetworkProtocol (see line 121).  Lets fix this while we're here as well.
Done

This is going to the user, so technically eth0 is wrong as well, but it definitely shouldn't be ethX, we should be using the interface name we were given.  I suspect this should be hardcoded to "NetworkProtocol" as that's the Id of this resource (see line 125).
Done

If there are mutiple D-bus objects implementing the xyz.openbmc_project.Network.EthernetInterface, Would you be writing the same dns server details on all the interface? or would it be fine to add it on one of the interface?

No, this patch only fixes NTP server properties.
Regarding dns server, we can get/set according to the corresponding Ethernet ID
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/ethernet.hpp#L1866-L1876

On a multiinterface system, we would be patching the ntp servers for all the interfaces???
we should only update the ntp server for the given interface.
in Redfish, we don't have a single interface.  It defines NTP servers for the system as a whole.  So long as we can resolve the ordering issue, I'm ok with setting all ethernet devices.

> in Redfish, we don't have a single interface.  It defines NTP servers for the system as a whole.  So long as we can resolve the ordering issue, I'm ok with setting all ethernet devices.

Please check this patch:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47344

> in Redfish, we don't have a single interface.  It defines NTP servers for the system as a whole.  So long as we can resolve the ordering issue, I'm ok with setting all ethernet devices.

Ed, Redfish is showing the interfaces what is being given by the back end.Now with this patch where we are updating the same NTP server on both the interfaces, lead to duplicate entry and I can see that George has pushed the patch for the same.

Considering that we now deduplicate between multiple endpoints on the GET, don't we also need to fail a call if it contains duplicates?  Otherwise, you would write

[1.1.1.1, 1.1.1.1]

and get back 

[1.1.1.1]

The `removeDuplicates` call has been moved to this method in the previous patch.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47344/5/redfish-core/lib/network_protocol.hpp#244
I thought we already had using definitions for these?  These probalby shouldn't exist only in the network namespace/file.
Removed
Isn't this todo now implemented?
Removed
possible nullptr dereference.
Done
The commit message talks about NTPServers in depth, but makes no mention that this is changing the behavior for DomainName as well.
Done

This behavior changed between the last patchset and this one.  I suspect the old behavior was ok, but just needed documented in the commit message;  Now this looks like it just duplicates domain names
Ack
Now we're no longer deduplicating the domain name data?
Done
